titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Sonny Burke Papers, ca. 1949-1951 and undated RL.00175
titlestmt.author: Processed by: Lois Schultz; machine-readable finding aid created by: Stephen Douglas Miller

publicationstmt.publisher: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2015-07-28 13:31:18 -0400.

change.item: Converted from dtd to schema, transformed with AT-import-fixer.xsl, and imported to Archivists Toolkit

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

physdesc.extent: 5 flat boxes; 76 complete big band charts

did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Library's online catalog.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Researchers must register and agree to copyright and privacy laws before using this collection.
All or portions of this collection may be housed off-site in Duke University's Library Service Center. The library may require up to 48 hours to retrieve these materials for research use.
Please contact Research Services staff before visiting the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library to use this collection.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in the Sonny Burke Collection have not been transferred to Duke University. The user is advised that rights for performance may be retained by the original composer and/or original arranger. For further information, see the section on copyright in the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The papers of Sonny Burke were acquired by Duke University in 1987.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note

eventgrp.event: Born Joseph Francis Burke in Scranton, Pennsylvania
Big band leader in New York (including Sam Donahue's band)
Active as an arranger & bandleader in major recording studios, including Decca Records; Burke was musical director of Reprise Records and was responsible for many of Frank Sinatra's albums
Bandleader for recordings of leading singers such as Ella Fitzgerald and Mel Torme.
Band arranger, including Charlie Spivak & Jimmy Dorsey bands
Is credited as co-composer of Midnight Sun, the Lionel Hampton tune with lyrics by Johnny Mercer.

list.item: Sonny Burke and his Orchestra I & II (1951)

bioghist.p: Further biographical information may be found in: The Guinness Encyclopedia of Popular Music. Chester, CT: New England Pub. Associates. 1992 , v. 1, p. 368.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The Sonny Burke Collection (chiefly undated, but some dated between Nov., 1949 and June, 1951) has as its focal point 76 arrangements of popular music for Big Band. These charts were used by Burke's band during the 1940's-1950's for performances in the United States and Mexico. Most of the arrangements appear to be by Sonny Burke, but other composers/arrangers include: Frank Erickson, Hal Schaefer, Stan Kenton, John Valentine Eppel, Laurindo Almeida, and Ray Conniff. Some of the arrangements were made for recordings on the Decca Records label. The most common instrumentation is for two alto saxophones/clarinets, tenor saxophone, baritone saxophone, four trumpets and four trombones, although other combinations exist. The instrumentation is noted for each title in the Container List.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged alphabetically by the title of the musical work, with the parts arranged in the score order described above. for each title, information about composer, arranger, and copyist is noted where available; chart number in the individual instrumental books or folders; instrumentation; date (where available); and provenance. The names of players are noted on the miscellaneous line where they are indicated on the parts. The miscellaneous folder contains unidentified works, single parts, programs, and a ticket for one of the concerts. All of the material consists of preservation photocopies of the originals, which were not retained.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Complete parts (Alto sax (2), tenor sax (1), baritone sax (1), trumpets (4), trombones (4)) for 3 arrangements. One has the notation: [chart #] 81, another is arranged by Frank Erickson.
2 Programs and a complimentary ticket for Saturday, July 5, 1952.
Miscellaneous unidentified or incomplete arrangements, including some scores. Some have titles:
Someone on Your Mind (1st alto sax)
The Sunny South by J. Bodewalt Lampe (2nd-3rd clarinets)
Them Their Eyes (baritone sax excerpt, trombone ending)
